item.title: Alert
item.description: ! Info! This is an informative message X ! Info! This is an informative message X ! Info! This is an informative message X <div class="alert"> <div class="alert__icon"> ! </div> <div class="alert__message"> <strong>Info!</strong> This is an informative message </div> <div class="alert__close"> X </div> </div> <div class="alert alert--success"> <div class="alert__icon"> ! </div> <div class="alert__message"> <strong>Info!</strong> This is an informative message </div> <div class="alert__close"> X </div> </div> <div class="alert alert--danger"> <div class="alert__icon"> !

item.title: Button
item.description: Buttons allow an application to communicate action and direct user intent. Three different types Solid Button Solid buttons look heavy on purpose. They direct the user’s attention to the primary action the application is suggesting that the user take. Outline Button Outline buttons provide a lighter weight button style. They are used to indicate a secondary action that compliments a primary action or to reduce visual noise when there are many action of equal importance on the page.

item.title: Form
item.description: Form, yo Label We'll never share your email with anyone else. Password Check me out Submit <form class="form"> <div class="form-group"> <label for="input1">Label</label> <input type="input1" class="form-control" id="input1" aria-describedby="emailHelp" placeholder="Enter email"> <small id="emailHelp" class="form-text text-muted">We'll never share your email with anyone else.</small> </div> <div class="form-group"> <label for="exampleInputPassword1">Password</label> <input type="password" class="form-control" id="exampleInputPassword1" placeholder="Password"> </div> <div class="form-check"> <label class="form-check-label"> <input type="checkbox" class="form-check-input"> Check me out </label> </div> <button type="submit" class="btn btn-primary">Submit</button> </form>

item.title: Tab
item.description: Tabs divide content into separate views which users navigate between. Tabs divide content into separate views which users navigate between. Design Guidelines Usage Use tabs for alternate views within the sidenav or main content area. Don’t use tabs to break user interactions into a series of steps. Serial workflows are best presented in a wizard. Avoid using tabs in cards and modals. Presentation Tabs appear in a single, non-scrollable row, above their content.
